items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Cities on Silk
items.abstract: Wearable aerial views: Azin Valy brings her love for maps into clothing and accessories.

items.title: Graphic Design: What a Trip
items.abstract: For Caroline Baumann, of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, vintage type settings and luggage labels from her Swiss grandparents hold a special place in her heart.

items.title: Municipal Identification Card Program Offers Free Cultural Benefits
items.abstract: Enrollment in the program includes free annual memberships to 40 institutions. Here’s a borough-by-borough list of highlights.

items.title: Review: In ‘City of Thorns,’ Ben Rawlence Tells a Refugee Camp’s Story
items.abstract: In this book, Mr. Rawlence spotlights nine people to describe life in a Kenyan refugee camp he calls the biggest in the world.
keywords: City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World's Largest Refugee Camp (Book)

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: Director of Manhattan’s Museum of Arts and Design to Step Down
items.abstract: Glenn Adamson, director of the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, has announced he will be stepping down.

items.title: A Pair of Cousins Who Make Furniture, and Sometimes Partner With Daft Punk
items.abstract: Cédric and Nicolas Hervet opened Hervet Manufacturier on Thursday, and the musician Thomas Bangalter documented the process.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: To Save the Sound of a Stradivarius, a Whole City Must Keep Quiet
items.abstract: A team in Cremona, Italy, wants to preserve every note from the world’s finest instruments before they become too fragile to play. But perfect recordings need silence. Lots of it.

items.title: A Beloved Provence-Based Wicker Workshop Comes to Paris
items.abstract: This week, Atelier Vime unveils its new showroom and a collaboration with the American artist Wayne Pate.

items.title: Nathan Glazer, Urban Sociologist and Outspoken Intellectual, Dies at 95
items.abstract: Mr. Glazer often waded into heated debates over contentious issues about race, ethnicity, immigration and education.

items.title: What’s on TV Saturday: Amanda Seales and ‘Austin City Limits’
items.abstract: A comic dissects sexuality and race in a new special on HBO. And Willie Nelson takes the stage on “Austin City Limits.”

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: City Harvest Moves Into an Expansive Space in Sunset Park, Brooklyn
items.abstract: Sushi, sashimi and steaks from a Las Vegas presence, a financial district outpost for Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar & Grill, and more restaurant news.

items.title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
items.abstract: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.

items.title: Cooper Hewitt Design Museum Gets a New Director
items.abstract: Maria Nicanor, an architecture curator and historian, takes on the Smithsonian position held by Caroline Baumann, who in 2020 was abruptly forced to resign.

items.title: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
items.abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?
